awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Design of Multisite Moderation Studies to Examine the Factors that Explain Treatment Effect Variation on Student Mathematics Achievement in Teacher Professional Development
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project submitted to the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, responsive to Program Solicitation NSF 15-555. Its purpose is to develop a comprehensive framework to inform and investigate treatment effect variation in teacher professional development (PD) studies using multisite moderation studies focused on the variables that affect the direction and magnitude of the relation between the treatment variable and the outcome variable. The study will accomplish four integrated research and education goals. The first goal will develop the statistical theory underlying the effective and efficient design of multisite moderation studies of professional development, and derive formulas for the statistical power and the minimum detectable effect size difference with confidence intervals for moderator effects in two- and three-level multisite randomized and nonrandomized studies. The second goal will apply a framework and statistical theory to empirically estimate the moderator effects and design parameters of existing Elementary Mathematics Specialists (EMS) programs, and demonstrate the calculation of the statistical power and the minimum detectable effect size difference for this EMS program using the formulas derived from the first goal. The third goal will execute the formulas derived from the first doal in the existing free-available software, and develop accompanying software documentation. Finally, the fourth goal will provide graduate students and researchers PD in using the results from this project to design multisite moderation studies. It will include developing curricular and instructional materials on the tools and conducting workshops using these materials.

The proposed research builds on data from an ongoing NSF-funded mathematics teacher PD study, which examines the average effects of the EMS certified teachers with the EMS non-certified teachers that are matched within schools or districts. The CAREER study will gather secondary data from the ongoing work on students' mathematics achievement; teachers' mathematical content knowledge; and covariates and potential moderators, such as type of school district, school, teacher, and student background information. Data analyses will focus on students' mathematics achievement gains empirical estimates of moderator effects using two- and three-level hierarchical linear modeling for moderation analyses; empirical estimates of design parameters necessary for power analyses; and demonstration of calculating the power and the minimum detectable effect size difference for this EMS program. Likewise, the project will develop software and documentation that make the complex statistical concepts broadly accessible and practical to applied researchers to implement the work developed from this study; as well as the training materials and design of the professional development workshops. The project will be evaluated both internally and externally through an advisory board and users of the software and PD materials. The main outcome of this effort will be a framework and tools to increase researchers' capacity to identify the factors and conditions that explain the treatment effect variation in teacher professional development; thus, improving teacher effectiveness through the rigorous evidence of research findings in response to questions regarding "work for whom, and under what circumstances", and interpreting and exploring the sources of the treatment effect variations.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

The purpose of this project was to develop a comprehensive framework to inform and guide the analytic design to investigate treatment effect variation in teacher professional development studies using multisite moderation studies. The proposed framework incorporated four integrated research and education goals: (1) develop statistical formulas to guide the design of moderator effects in multisite randomized and nonrandomized studies, (2) develop empirical estimates of the moderator effects and the design parameters for an elementary mathematics teacher training program and demonstrate how to implement these formulas to design teacher development studies, (3) execute the formulas in the existing software (PowerUp!, Dong & Maynard, 2013), and (4) develop training materials and conduct workshops on the design of multisite moderation studies of teacher development.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The framework and tools developed in this study can improve the design of multisite moderation studies to detect the moderator effects and will increase researchers’ capacity to effectively and efficiently plan teacher development studies to identify various factors to account for the treatment effect variability. Multisite randomized trials (MRTs), in which the units for random assignment are the lower levels (e.g., student or classrooms), are the most common designs, followed by cluster randomized trials (CRTs), in which, the units for random assignment are the top level (Spybrook & Raudenbush, 2009; Spybrook, Shi, & Kelcy, 2016). However, literature has not developed a comprehensive framework to guide analytic design of moderator effects of professional development studies in multisite randomized and nonrandomized studies. This study can advance the field by developing conceptual framework, power formulas, and software for tests of moderation effects in multisite randomized and nonrandomized studies, and investigating the effects of various potential moderators (e.g., characteristics of students, teachers, and schools) in explaining the treatment variation for an Elementary Mathematics Specialists program.

 

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts of this study lie in the implementation of the statistical formulas in one of the most widely used power analysis programs for designing multilevel studies (PowerUp!, Dong & Maynard, 2013), the development of training materials, and conducting professional workshops. These results can have the potential to substantively impact our understanding of treatment effect variation in teacher development because comprehensive tools and training will be provided to researchers to design rigorous multisite moderation studies. The framework and tools are expected to expand the scope and enhance the quality of evidence generated though multisite randomized and nonrandomized studies in STEM teacher development in examining the programs 'work for whom and under what circumstances'.

 

Outcomes:

During the entire life of the award, we accomplished the proposed goals. We published seven journal papers regarding causal moderation analysis and power analysis for moderation in two- and three-level multisite cluster/individual randomized trials in high impact journals such as Multivariate Behavioral Research, Journal of Education, and Journal of Experimental Education. We conducted a dozen of paper presentations and workshops at the professional conferences such as the American Educational Research Association and the Society of Research for Educational Effectiveness. In addition, we created software, 'PowerUp!-Moderator-MRTs' (https://www.causalevaluation.org/power-analysis.html) and PowerUpR shiny application (https://powerupr.shinyapps.io/index/) to assistant researchers to design multisite moderation studies.

 

Disclaimer: 

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.


Last Modified: 04/17/2024
Modified by: Nianbo Dong
